subject: Re: [junit] Automated tests for report output?
msgSnippet: ... What does validation of the layout mean?  I suspect that if you can clarify this, you will have answered your question. There are probably at least three
messageBody:
On Mon, 20 Oct 2003, dchurchv wrote:

> Anyone have any thoughts on automated testing for application output?
> (e.g. PDF or other concrete output format)
>
> I think this is a special case of UI testing, without the ability
> actual verify things at a component level (like with UIs).
> Currently, we have to do this by visually inspecting the report
> output, but I'd love to be able to add some level of automation to
> this...
>
> The usual argument here is that a report (or UI) is just
> a "presentation", and that testing the underlying data queries and
> logic is sufficient. We do all of this, but I feel like something's
> missing: some sort of validation of the layout.

What does 'validation of the layout' mean? I suspect that if you can
clarify this, you will have answered your question.

There are probably at least three questions to be dealt with:

1 Is the data being presented valid?
2 Is the PDF (or whatever) representation of the text/graphics
correct?
3 Is the data being rendered as expected?

The first and second are traditional unit testing problems. You do the
first kind of testing, Adobe or whoever presumably has done the second.

Perhaps an example of a failure in the third area would be output where
data that should be in tables appears in the body of the text or vice
versa, or data that should be represented as a pie chart appears as a
bar graph instead. So you want to make assertions like

assertTrue ( outputIsPieChart(datasetA) );

> Especially for applications whose whole purpose is report generation,
> I wonder how people are doing this (if at all)?
